page.title: 13HOUSING - ETTRICK VALLEY>
page.content: FARMS AND HOMES The earliest habitation in this part of Ettrick Valley was a raised hillock on the valley floor where an ancient hut circle stood clear of the regular floods. Present buildings have been sited on the hill slopes or beside the main road. Most of the buildings retain their original character of farm or farm workers' houses. At Shankend the old smithy cottages and the East Lodge at Thirlestane are all modernised. The farm houses are large with many back stairs, kitchens and pantries once required by the maids and herds.Shepherds'cottages have a byre built alongside. It was traditional that the shepherd had a house cow as part of his annual wages. Tushielaw Inn retains its original character as a l9th century coaching inn.
